chunk text: scientific method is the process by which scientists approach their work
topic: What is science?

chunk text: experimental science is the use of experiments to obtain information
topic: What is science?

chunk text: applied science is the use of scientific research to meet certain human needs
topic: What is science?

chunk text: spontaneous generation is the appearance of living organisms from non-living matter
topic: What are the main steps of the scientific method?

chunk text: hypothesis is an educated guess about what a biologist thinks the explanation of an observation will be. But it has to be stated in such a way that it can be tested by an experiment
topic: What are the main steps of the scientific method?

chunk text: prediction is an educated guess as to how the biologist thinks his/her experiment will turn out
topic: What are the main steps of the scientific method?

chunk text: control group is the standard group in an experiment in which the experimental groups are compared with
topic: Control group and experimental group

chunk text: experimental group is the group in an experiment which is being experimented on in order to compare with the control group
topic: Control group and experimental group

chunk text: independent variable is the variable that the experimenter changes to see if this affects the performance of the dependent variable. Does the presence or absence of a drug in a tablet (independent variable) affect the recovery of the patient?
topic: What do we mean by cause and effect?

chunk text: dependent variable is the factor in an experiment that the scientist measures to see if it changes when the independent variable is changed
topic: What do we mean by cause and effect?

chunk text: fair test is an experiment in which the only difference between different repeats of the experiment is the different values of the independent variable, all other factors that could affect the outcome have been kept constant (they have been controlled)
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: controlled variables are factors other than the independent variable that are kept constant in order to avoid influencing results
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: confounding variable is a factor that can’t be controlled which may influence the result of the experiment
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: accuracy is how precisely something has been measured or counted
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: reliability is a measure of how dependable and consistent the results of an experiment are
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: anomalous results are really odd results that do not fit the general pattern
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: colorimeter measures how much light passes through a liquid
topic: Accuracy, reliability and validity in scientific experiments

chunk text: balances are apparatus used for measuring mass
topic: What apparatus do biologists use?

chunk text: dissect means to cut apart or separate tissue for anatomical study
topic: What apparatus do biologists use?

chunk text: agar is a jelly-like substance obtained from seaweed, used for culturing micro-organisms in a Petri dish
topic: What do biologists use in the laboratory?

chunk text: to culture organisms means to grow them under special conditions that are likely to help their growth
topic: What do biologists use in the laboratory?

chunk text: optical microscope uses beams of light to produce magnified images
topic: What do biologists use in the laboratory?

chunk text: electron microscope uses beams of electrons to produce magnified images
topic: What do biologists use in the laboratory?

chunk text: centrifuge is a machine that spins to separate solids from liquids
topic: What do biologists use in the laboratory?

chunk text: quadrat is a small frame used for ecological or population studies
topic: What do biologists use in the field?

chunk text: transect line is a straight line through an area
topic: What do biologists use in the field?

chunk text: random means having no specific pattern, purpose or objective
topic: What do biologists use in the field?

chunk text: bias means tending towards a specific result
topic: What do biologists use in the field?

chunk text: biotechnology is the use of micro-organisms and enzymes that will benefit mankind
topic: Biotechnology

chunk text: AIDS is a disease that severely reduces the body’s immune functioning
topic: 1.4 Biology and HIV/AIDS

chunk text: HIV is the virus that causes AIDS
topic: 1.4 Biology and HIV/AIDS

chunk text: retrovirus is a virus that inserts its RNA into the host cell where it is ‘reverse transcribed’ to DNA
topic: How can biology help in the fight against AIDS?

chunk text: anti-retroviral drugs are drugs that target retroviruses and prevent them replicating
topic: How can biology help in the fight against AIDS?

chunk text: highly active anti-retroviral therapy (HAART) is treatment using a combination of anti-retroviral drugs
topic: How can biology help in the fight against AIDS?

chunk text: element is a substance that is made of only one kind of atom
topic: Which chemical elements are found most frequently in living organisms?

chunk text: atoms are the smallest particles of a chemical element
topic: Which chemical elements are found most frequently in living organisms?

chunk text: bond is the energy that joins atoms together to form a molecule
topic: Which chemical elements are found most frequently in living organisms?

chunk text: molecule is a number of atoms bonded together
topic: Which chemical elements are found most frequently in living organisms?

chunk text: compound is a substance made from molecules containing more than one kind of atom in a fixed ratio
topic: Which chemical elements are found most frequently in living organisms?

chunk text: valency is the number of bonds an atom can make with other atoms
topic: Which chemical elements are found most frequently in living organisms?

chunk text: hydrogen bonds are bonds that join the oxygen in one water molecule to the hydrogen in another
topic: Why is water so important to living things?

chunk text: specific heat capacity is the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 g of a substance by 1 oC
topic: Why is water so important to living things?

chunk text: density is the mass in kg of 1 dm3 of a substance (or the mass in g of 1 cm3 of a substance)
topic: Why is water so important to living things?

chunk text: latent heat of vaporisation is the energy used in converting a liquid to a gas at the same temperature
topic: Why is water so important to living things?

chunk text: surface tension is the tension at the surface of a liquid resulting from unbalanced forces acting on the molecules at the surface
topic: Why is water so important to living things?

chunk text: reactant is a substance that takes part in a chemical reaction
topic: Water as a reactant.

chunk text: hydrolysis means using water to split large molecules
topic: Water as a reactant.

chunk text: carbohydrate is a molecule that contains the elements carbon, hydrogen and oxygen
topic: What are carbohydrates and why do we need them?

chunk text: starch is a complex carbohydrate that stores chemical energy in plants
topic: What are carbohydrates and why do we need them?

chunk text: glycogen is a complex carbohydrate that stores chemical energy in animals
topic: What are carbohydrates and why do we need them?

chunk text: monosaccharide is a single sugar
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: isomers are molecules with the same chemical composition, but a different arrangement of atoms
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: functional group is a group of atoms within a molecule that behaves in a particular way
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: aldoses are monosaccharides with an aldehyde group in the molecule
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: ketoses are monosaccharides with a ketone group in the molecule
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: disaccharide is a sugar formed when two monosaccharides join together
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: maltose is a disaccharide derived from two α-glucose molecules
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: sucrose is a disaccharide derived from an α-glucose molecule and a fructose molecule
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: condensation is the process in which two molecules combine to form a larger molecule, producing a smaller molecule (often water) as a by-product
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: glycosidic bond is the bond that holds two monosaccharide units together
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: polysaccharide is a carbohydrate whose molecules consist of a number of monosaccharide molecules bonded together
topic: What different types of carbohydrates are there?

chunk text: amylose is a long unbranched chain of α-glucose molecules
topic: Starch

chunk text: amylopectin is a chain of α-glucose molecules with many branches
topic: Starch

chunk text: covalently bonded hydrocarbon chain means a chain of carbon atoms, covalently bonded to each other and to one, or more, hydrogen atoms
topic: Triglycerides

chunk text: carboxyl group is acid radical -COOH. It releases H+ into aqueous solution to make the solution acidic
topic: Triglycerides

chunk text: saturated fatty acid means all the carbon–carbon bonds in the hydrocarbon chain are single bonds
topic: Triglycerides

chunk text: monounsaturated fatty acid means one of the carbon–carbon bonds is a double bond
topic: Triglycerides

chunk text: polyunsaturated fatty acid means more than one carbon–carbon bond is a double bond
topic: Triglycerides

chunk text: ester bond is the bond that forms between a carboxyl group and a hydroxyl group
topic: Triglycerides

chunk text: hydrophilic means water-loving
topic: Phospholipids

chunk text: hydrophobic means water-hating
topic: Phospholipids

chunk text: bilayer means two layers sandwiched together
topic: Phospholipids

chunk text: amino acids are the building blocks of proteins and have two functional groups – the amino group and the carboxyl group. This allows them to behave both as a base and as an acid
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: peptide bond is the bond that links two amino acids
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: polypeptide is a linear polymer consisting of amino acid residues bonded together in a chain forming a part or all of a protein molecule
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: primary structure is the sequence formed by amino acids
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: secondary structure is formed when a polypeptide chain folds itself into another structure
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: α-helix is a coiled secondary structure of a polypeptide
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: β-pleated sheet is a folded pleated sheet secondary structure of a polypeptide
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: tertiary structure is folding of the secondary structure of a polypeptide by the formation of new bonds to hold it in place
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: quaternary structure is structures formed when two or more polypeptide chains (folded into a tertiary structure) become associated in the final structure of the protein
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: haemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying molecule in the blood
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: collagen is fibrous protein found in many tissues in mammals
topic: Why do we need proteins?

chunk text: DNA is a huge molecule made up of two strands of nucleotides wound into a double helix
topic: What are nucleic acids?

chunk text: RNA is a molecule made up of one strand of nucleotides
topic: What are nucleic acids?

chunk text: active site is the part of an enzyme molecule that binds with its substrate so that the enzyme can catalyse the chemical reaction
topic: What are enzyme molecules like?

chunk text: substrate is a substance upon which an enzyme acts in a biochemical reaction
topic: What are enzyme molecules like?

chunk text: enzyme–substrate complex is the intermediate formed, temporarily, when an enzyme binds to its substrate
topic: What are enzyme molecules like?

chunk text: catalyst is a substance that speeds up a chemical reaction and remains unchanged at the end of the reaction
topic: What are catalysts?

chunk text: Enzyme Commission is a body set up to produce a systematic way of naming enzymes
topic: How do we name and classify enzymes?

chunk text: activation energy is the energy required to start off a chemical reaction
topic: How do enzymes act as catalysts?

chunk text: lock-and-key model proposes that the shapes of the substrate molecules are complementary to that of the active site
topic: How do enzymes lower activation energy?

chunk text: induced-fit model means the active site and substrate do not complement each other but the binding of substrate molecules produces a change in shape in the active site, allowing the substrate to fit the active site
topic: How do enzymes lower activation energy?

chunk text: turnover rate is the number of molecules of reactants that form enzyme–substrate complexes with each molecule of an enzyme, per second
topic: The induced-fit model

chunk text: denature means the alteration of the tertiary structure of a protein; in living cells this is reversible
topic: How hot must it be?

chunk text: optimum temperature is the temperature at which an enzyme works most efficiently
topic: How hot must it be?

chunk text: pH scale is a measure of the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution
topic: How acidic must it be?

chunk text: competitive inhibitor is a molecule that inhibits enzyme activity by competing with the substrate for the active site
topic: Competitive inhibitors

chunk text: non-competitive inhibitor is a molecule that alters the conformation of the active site by binding with the allosteric site of the enzyme; it prevents the substrate from binding and inhibits enzyme activity
topic: Non-competitive inhibitors

chunk text: end-product inhibition means when an end product inhibits the enzyme controlling the first stage of a reaction sequence
topic: How do inhibitors control enzyme activity in living cells?

chunk text: activator is a substance that removes an inhibitor
topic: How do inhibitors control enzyme activity in living cells?

chunk text: calibrating means correlate the readings of an instrument with a standard
topic: How big are cells?

chunk text: arbitrary units are units we use when we don’t know actual dimensions but we know the mathematical relationship between different conditions
topic: what are the consequences of the different sizes of cells?

chunk text: division of labour is the specialisation of different parts to carry out certain functions
topic: 4.2 Types of cells

chunk text: prokaryotic cell is a type of cell that does not have a nucleus. The word prokaryotic is derived from Greek pro (before) and karyos (nuclear)
topic: what are prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

chunk text: eukaryotic cell is a type of cell that has a nucleus. The word eukaryotic is derived from Greek eu (true) and karyos (nuclear)
topic: what are prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

chunk text: organelles are individual structures in a cell with a specific function
topic: what are prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

chunk text: endoplasmic reticulum is the network of membranes in a cell
topic: what are prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

chunk text: membrane-bound organelles are organelles surrounded by membranes
topic: what are prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

chunk text: heterotrophic means these cells must absorb organic molecules ‘ready-made’
topic: How did eukaryotic cells originate?

chunk text: autotrophic cells are capable of making their own organic molecules from inorganic ones, usually by photosynthesis
topic: How did eukaryotic cells originate?

chunk text: endosymbiont theory is the theory of the origin of eukaryotic cells
topic: How did eukaryotic cells originate?

chunk text: 70S and 80S ribosomes means the ‘S’ stands for ‘sedimentation coefficient’ and is a measure of their mass
topic: 4.2 Types of cells

chunk text: plasma membrane/cell surface membrane is the membrane at the surface of all cells that isolates the cell from the environment and controls the exchange of substances between cell and environment
topic: what is the importance of the cell membrane?

chunk text: integral proteins are proteins that span both phospholipid layers in a plasma membrane
topic: what is the plasma membrane like?

chunk text: channel proteins are integral proteins with pores that allow ions to pass through the membrane
topic: what is the plasma membrane like?

chunk text: carrier proteins are integral proteins that move medium-sized particles across the membrane
topic: what is the plasma membrane like?

chunk text: peripheral proteins are proteins that span only one of the two phospholipid layers
topic: what is the plasma membrane like?

chunk text: glycoproteins are proteins with chains of sugars attached
topic: what is the plasma membrane like?

chunk text: cholesterol is a sterol lipid
topic: what is the plasma membrane like?

chunk text: water potential is the concentration of water molecules
topic: Osmosis

chunk text: isotonic solution is having the same water potential as the cell
topic: What happens to cells placed in solutions of different concentrations?

chunk text: hypertonic solution is having lower water potential than the cell
topic: What happens to cells placed in solutions of different concentrations?

chunk text: hypotonic solution is having a higher water potential than the cell
topic: What happens to cells placed in solutions of different concentrations?

chunk text: cristae are partial partitions in mitochondria
topic: Mitochondria

chunk text: fluid matrix is where some of the reactions of aerobic respiration take place in mitochondria
topic: Mitochondria

chunk text: grana are membranous regions in a chloroplast
topic: Chloroplast

chunk text: thylakoids are flattened sacs inside a chloroplast where photosynthesis takes place
topic: Chloroplast

chunk text: phosphorylated nucleotide means the adding of one or more phosphate groups to a molecule
topic: What is the ATP molecule like?

chunk text: adenosine di-phosphate means removing the third phosphate from ATP leaves a phosphorylated nucleotide with two nucleotides
topic: What is the ATP molecule like?

chunk text: ATP synthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of ATP
topic: How is ATP produced in a cell?

chunk text: substrate level phosphorylation is when another molecule (substrate) is able to transfer a phosphate group directly to ADP
topic: How is ATP produced in aerobic respiration?

chunk text: respiratory substrates are organic molecules that can be respired
topic: How is ATP produced in aerobic respiration?

chunk text: reduce means to decrease the oxidation state of a substance
topic: How is ATP produced in aerobic respiration?

chunk text: oxidise means to increase the oxidation state of a substance
topic: How is ATP produced in aerobic respiration?

chunk text: matrix is the fluid in the mitochondrion in which the reactions of the Krebs cycle take place
topic: What are the stages of aerobic respiration of glucose?

chunk text: electron transport chain is a series of molecules along which electrons travel
topic: What are the stages of aerobic respiration of glucose?

chunk text: oxidative phosphorylation is the oxygen-dependent production of ATP
topic: What are the stages of aerobic respiration of glucose?

chunk text: coenzyme A is a coenzyme derived from pantothenic acid needed for respiration
topic: What happens in the link reaction?

chunk text: acetyl coenzyme A is produced by the reaction of coenzyme A with a molecule of pyruvate
topic: What happens in the link reaction?

chunk text: dehydrogenation is removing hydrogen from a molecule
topic: What happens in the link reaction?

chunk text: decarboxylation is removing carbon from a molecule
topic: What happens in the link reaction?

chunk text: oxaloacetate is an ester of oxaloacetic acid
topic: What happens in the Krebs cycle?

chunk text: citrate is an ester of citric acid
topic: What happens in the Krebs cycle?

chunk text: terminal electron acceptor is the final molecule at the end of the electron transport chain to accept an electron
topic: What happens in the electron transport chain and chemiosmosis?

chunk text: transduced means conversion of energy from one form to another
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: light-dependent reactions are reactions of photosynthesis dependent on light
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: photosensitive pigments are pigments having a response to light
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: chlorophyll is a green pigment that absorbs blue and red light
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: thylakoids are flattened sacs inside a chloroplast on which light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis take place
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: photosystems are the biochemical mechanism by which chlorophyll absorbs light energy
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: photosystem I is a photosystem in photosynthetic light reactions. Discovered before photosystem II
topic: Photosynthesis

chunk text: reaction centre molecule is where light-dependent reactions begin
topic: What is the structure of a photosystem?

chunk text: antenna complex is an array of protein and chlorophyll light-harvesting molecules embedded in the thylakoid membrane
topic: What is the structure of a photosystem?

chunk text: absorption spectrum is the range of wavelengths a molecule absorbs
topic: What is the structure of a photosystem?

chunk text: action spectrum is the photosynthesis effectiveness of each wavelength
topic: What is the structure of a photosystem?

chunk text: primary electron acceptor is the first molecule to accept the excited electron displaced from a chlorophyll molecule
topic: Photosystem I and photosystem II

chunk text: photolysis is the light-dependent splitting of water
topic: Photosystem I and photosystem II

chunk text: photosynthetic unit is an arrangement of molecules capable of carrying out all the reactions in the light-dependent stage of photosynthesis.
topic: Photosystem I and photosystem II

chunk text: non-cyclic photophosphorylation is the formation of ATP via photosystem II
topic: Photosystem I and photosystem II

chunk text: cyclic photophosphorylation is the use of only photosystem I to generate ATP
topic: Photosystem I and photosystem II

chunk text: ribulose bisphosphate is a five-carbon compound in the stroma
topic: How is carbohydrate synthesised in the light-independent reactions?

chunk text: principle of limiting factors means limitation by a factor that is present in a limiting quantity.
topic: What factors affect the rate of photosynthesis?

chunk text: photorespiration is a process involving the oxidation of carbon.
topic: C3 photosynthesis and photorespiration

chunk text: C4 photosynthesis means light-dependent reactions are the same as in C3 photosynthesis but the first compound formed in the light-independent reactions contains four carbons, not three.
topic: C4 photosynthesis
